body: On a cursory look, it seems weird that `getpeername()` is failing. Do you know why that's happening?

@yashykt the only correlating event from the logs is the restarts of the client. But I failed to reproduce it myself.
While the reason for getpeername() failure is unknown, the error handling should be such that grpc server recovers. The current code does not recover once it hits the issue and stops accepting further connections from all the clients.

@ssachinbharadwaj I'm not sure how the server's `fd` could get corrupted in your case, there's almost nothing between `accept` and `getpeername`. Even if the client closes the connection in between these calls, or someone deletes the socket file, `getpeername` should succeed and have an empty string. By any chance is your server `fork`ing at this point?

What flavor of Linux are you running?

> 2. Even if "Bad file descriptor" is seen, it should recover

I'm not sure this is true. If there's a good explanation for how the fd could be corrupted, then it would make more sense to continue on with server operations.

> I'm not sure [if the server should recover]. If there's a good explanation for how the fd could be corrupted, then it would make more sense to continue on with server operations.

But to your point @ssachinbharadwaj, if the server should stop accepting incoming connections due to inexplicable corruption of some kind, it should do so LOUDLY. Right now this is a silent failure.

issue.title: [server] Better logging on shutdown from failed getpeername

labels.name: release notes: no
labels.description: Indicates if PR should not be in release notes

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
Regardless of whether we change server behavior to continue running after a failed `getpeername` on accept, this improves the logs for the current server behavior.

Related to #35076

body:
@drfloob Thank you for looking into this.

> By any chance is your server `fork`ing at this point?

No
> 
> What flavor of Linux are you running?

It is Juniper's Junos OS Evolved a.k.a "EVO"

> I'm not sure this is true. If there's a good explanation for how the fd could be corrupted, then it would make more sense to continue on with server operations.

At this point, we are not too sure of the reason of "Bad file descriptor"
While I agree that we need to identify the reason which lands up in this scenario. Should it be handled in such a way that the server does not give up listening
"Bad file descriptor" is one of the failure and there could be many other failure scenarios such as {EBADF, EFAULT, EINVAL, ENOBUFS, ENOTCONN, ENOTSOCK}
In any of the scenario, if the server stops listening completely, then it could be a problem (unless the reason is unrecoverable for example: ENOBUFS)

issue.title: [server] Keep server running after failed UDS `getpeername`

labels.name: release notes: no
labels.description: Indicates if PR should not be in release notes

repository.name: grpc
repository.description: C++ based gRPC (C++, Python, Ruby, Objective-C, PHP, C#)

issue.body:
Closes #35076. See discussion there for context.

Previously, if `getpeername` failed on a recently-accepted Unix domain socket, the server would shut down. It's unclear if there's any valid reason `getpeername` would fail here, we could be looking at system issues / data corruption, but it may be implementation-dependent. I did not find a man page that specified this behavior: getpeername on a server errors with `EBADF` when a client closes its end of a UDS connection; the server's fd should still be valid. I was not able to reproduce the failure on recent Linux/Mac systems where clients close their connection after a listener accepted (basic, non-gRPC test: listener accepts a connection and sleeps, client closes their end, then listener wakes up and calls getpeername).

If there are no valid reasons `getpeername` would fail in these spots, gRPC behavior is essentially undefined - we cannot defensively code around system failures in every place they may occur. If this _is_ a valid situation on some platforms, then this fix keeps the server alive as one would hope. There are arguments to be made for shutting down servers if the system is unstable, but I can't find an objectively correct behavior here. For those reasons, I think it may be best to keep the server running, which is what this PR does.

body: @ssachinbharadwaj I've made the change, it should be in the 1.62 release. I still half suspect you're facing either (A) some kind of unstable system, or (B) an odd implementation of getpeername. But hopefully this helps.
